items.item_details:
Item:  9.05
	 
	 
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Resolution #2010/2011-22
	 
Fred Korematsu Day of Civil Liberties and the Constitution
	 
	 
WHEREAS, the battle for civil liberties has been championed by ordinary Americans who have had the courage to stand up and fight for their basic Constitutional rights; and
	 
WHEREAS,  Fred T. Korematsu was one of these individuals, who refused to comply with Civilian Exclusion Order 34, based on the federal Executive Order 9066, which imposed strict curfew regulations and required 120,000 Japanese Americans to leave their homes to be incarcerated in American concentration camps during World War II; and
	 
WHEREAS,  Mr. Korematsu was arrested and convicted, but fought back because he believed the conviction went against the basic freedoms guaranteed to him by the U.S. Constitution, and 
	 
WHEREAS, Mr. Korematsu’s conviction was ultimately overturned in 1984; a decision that influenced the US government’s passage of the Civil Liberties Act of 1988, which recognized that a grave injustice was done by forced relocation and incarceration of civilian Americans because of wartime prejudice; and 
	 
WHEREAS, current California law designates a number of days as having special significance, when public schools are encouraged to observe and conduct suitable commemorative exercises as specified 
	 
WHEREAS, the History-Social Science Framework for California Public Schools, Kindergarten through Grade Twelve, states that the history curriculum at each grade level relating to community, state, region, nation and the world must reflect and integrate the experiences of men and women of different racial, religious and ethnic groups; and 
	 
WHEREAS,  the California Assembly and State Senate passed AB 1775, the Fred Korematsu Day of Civil Liberties and the Constitution, without opposition and Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger signed this bill into law on September 23, 2010;
	 
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the East Side Union High School District encourages all schools and teachers to observe the Fred T. Korematsu Day of Civil Liberties and the Constitution on January 30, or the days surrounding it, and conduct exercises commemorating the life of Fred Korematsu and recognizing the importance of preserving civil liberties, even in times of real or perceived crisis.
	 
PASSED AND ADOPTED this 20th day of January, 2011 by the Governing Board of the East Side Union High School District at its regular meeting held at 830 N. Capitol Avenue, San Jose, State of California. 
	 
	 
AYES:   ________
	 
NOES:  ________
	 
ABSENT:  ______
	 
ABSTAIN:  ______
	 
	 
I certify the foregoing resolution was duly introduced, passed, and adopted by the East Side Union High School District Board of Trustees at a meeting held on January 20, 2011.
	 
	 
	 
_________________________
Clerk
ESUHSD Board of Trustees
items.item_text: Adopt Resolution #2010/2010-22 Fred Korematsu Day of Civil Liberties and the Constitution - Van Le, Board Clerk
items.item_text_raw: 9.05 Adopt Resolution #2010/2010-22 Fred Korematsu Day of Civil Liberties and the Constitution - Van Le, Board Clerk

meeting_sections.section_name: BOARD/SUPERINTENDENT - OPERATIONAL ITEMS/BOARD DISCUSSION AND/OR ACTION

items.item_details:
Item:  10.01
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction; and Vito Chiala, Principal
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Overfelt High School Presentation
	 
Career Technical Education at Overfelt High School is a critical component of our plan to prepare all students to be graduate ready for both college and 21st Century Careers.  Overfelt High School has four California Partnership Academies serving students from 10th  through 12th grades.  Research has shown that academies increase students' engagement and connectedness which results in improved attendance, behavior, and academic achievement.  Academies at Overfelt High School generate grant funds and corporate donations while providing an effective learning environment.  Our presentation to the Board will highlight two of our career technical education academies:  Electronics and Multimedia.
items.item_text: Overfelt High School Presentation - Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Vito Chiala, Principal
items.item_text_raw: 10.01 Overfelt High School Presentation - Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Vito Chiala, Principal

items.item_details:
Item:  10.02
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public  Hearing at Approximately 6:30 p.m. on the State Board of Education Waiver
	 
BACKGROUND
	 
On behalf of its school, the District takes seriously its responsibilities under state and federal law to communicate the various aspects of performance covered by the School Accountability Report Card (SARC).  The District seeks to ensure that our parents and community members have an accurate, complete, and up-to-date SARC from which they can understand each school's performance and make decisions on behalf of their students.
	 
At its November 2010 meeting, the State Board of Education approved the 2010-11 School Accountability Report Card template and, at the same time, received a report from the California Department of Education that, due to budget and staffing reductions, the department would not be able to fill in some of the data that typically is provided to districts as they prepare their SARC's.  This shift in responsibility for that data collection and reporting to each district (and school) now requires district and school sites to take on additional duties just as the holidays approach.
	 
Because of the lateness in approving the template and the necessity for school districts to assume responsibility for manually gathering and inputting some of the data required for the 2010-11 SARC posting on February 1, the district and its schools are seeking a 60-day extension from the statutorily-required posting date of February 1.
	 
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE: 
N/A
	 
FISCAL IMPACT: 
N/A
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Hold Public Hearing to consider level of support for the General Waiver Request to the State Board of Education.
items.item_text: Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:30 p.m. on the State Board of Education Waiver - Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
items.item_text_raw: 10.02 Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:30 p.m. on the State Board of Education Waiver - Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  10.03
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Kirsten King,  Director of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Approve State Board of Education General Waiver Request:  60-Day Extension for the Posting of the School Accountability Report Card (SARC) 
	 
On behalf of its school, the District takes seriously its responsibilities under state and federal law to communicate the various aspects of performance covered by the School Accountability Report Card (SARC).  The District seeks to ensure that our parents and community members have an accurate, complete, and up-to-date SARC from which they can understand each school's performance and make decisions on behalf of their students.
	 
At its November 2010 meeting, the State Board of Education approved the 2010-11 School Accountability Report Card template and, at the same time, received a report from the California Department of Education that, due to budget and staffing reductions, the department would not be able to fill in some of the data that typically is provided to districts as they prepare their SARC's.  This shift in responsibility for that data collection and reporting to each district (and school) now requires district and school sites to take on additional duties just as the holidays approach.
	 
Because of the lateness in approving the template and the necessity for school districts to assume responsibility for manually gathering and inputting some of the data required for the 2010-11 SARC posting on February 1, the district and its schools are seeking a 60-day extension from the statutorily-required posting date of February 1.
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Approve the State Board of Education General Waiver Request.

items.item_text_raw: 10.03 Approve State Board of Education General Waiver Request: 60-Day Extension for the Posting of the School Accountability Report Card (SARC) - Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Kirsten King, Director of Instruction

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  10.04
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Kirsten King,  Director of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Accept Enrollment Update for Calero High School
	 
The Office of Public School Construction requires that an enrollment update report, which establishes the base line enrollment for the Calero campus prior to the school opening, be publicly submitted and approved at a regularly held board meeting. This base line will allow East Side to obtain modernization grants based on this base line enrollment number.
	 
The Calero campus will house a continuation high school, the Post Senior Program for disabled students, and a modified independent study program.
	 
The projected number of students eligible for the Post Senior Program for the 2012-13 school year is 180 with 172 qualifying as severely disabled and 8 non-severely disabled. The actual classroom capacity for the Post Senior Program at Calero is 108. The plan is to implement a rotating community--based program for these students so that the population rotates through the facility and community--based activities, thus doubling the usage of the existing space.
The projected enrollment for the continuation high school is 260 students. This aligns with the number of rooms and a class size requirement for continuation high schools of 26.  Currently, the district has a greater need for alternative education programs for its current student population and it is anticipated that the continuation high school on the Calero campus will operate at full capacity.
The projected enrollment for the modified independent study program is 60 which is based on two sessions of 30 students rotating through the facility each day. This will provide a need for an existing population of students who would benefit from being placed into this type of alternative setting.
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Accept Update for Calero High School.
items.item_text: Accept Enrollment Update for Calero High School - Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
items.item_text_raw: 10.04 Accept Enrollment Update for Calero High School - Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  10.05
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Robert Ibarra, Coordinator of Professional Development/Migrant Education
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Receive the Third Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint Quarterly Report for Period Covering October 1, 2010  through December 31, 2010 as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727)
	 
	 
BACKGROUND
As a result of the Williams Case (EC 35186), referred to as a landmark Superior Court case requires that every California public school provide each student with, at the very least, sufficient textbooks and instructional materials; clean, safe and functional buildings and facilities; and permanent, appropriately trained and assigned teachers.  Additionally, under the settlement of the Valenzuela / CAHSEE Settlement (EC 37254) students in grades 10 to 12 inclusive shall be notified of services available to students up to two consecutive years after the completion of grade 12 who have not yet passed the CAHSEE.
 
School districts shall support summarized data on the nature and resolution of all Williams Complaints and Valenzuela / CAHSEE Complaints on a quarterly basis to the governing board and the county superintendent of schools.  The report shall include the number of complaints by general subject area with the number of resolved and unresolved complaints.
 
The attached report indicates the number of complaints filed from October 1, 2010 through December 31, 2010.  
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Senate Bill 6 (Williams)
State Instructional Materials Allocation
District Instructional Materials Budget
Other Categorical Funds as Appropriate
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
None
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
The administration recommends that the Governing Board accept the Fourth Quarterly Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint Report for the period covering October 1, 2010 through December 31, 2010, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727).
items.item_text: Receive the Fourth Valenzuela/CASHEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint Quarterly Report for Period Covering October 1, 2010 through December 31, 2010 as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727) - Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Robert Ibarra, Coordinator of Professional Development/Migrant Education

It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the contracts for professional services as listed in the attachment and to delegate authority to the Superintendent or designee to amend said contracts and purchase orders on an as needed basis, including funding.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  14.10
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Business Services Division
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Accept Warrant Register for the Month of December 2010
	 
	 
Attached is a list of warrants issued during the month of December 2010, in response to board Policy 3314 Payment for Goods and Services adopted by the board in May 2009.  The Policy states that, “The Board shall approve all warrants (checks) at a regularly scheduled Board meeting".  While there is no legal requirement for Board approval of issued warrants, this list and future lists will add to the “transparency” of when the Board approves purchase orders, contracts and other authorized expenses as per Board Policies.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept the Warrant Register for the month of December 2010.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept the Warrant Register for the month of December 2010.

items.item_text_raw: 14.10 Accept Warrant Register for the Month of December 2010

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  14.11
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Business Services Division
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Approve Change Order #1 for the Expanded Lighting Scope at Santa Teresa High School High School
	 
	 
The five buildings at Santa Teresa High School were originally thought to be part of the modernization program but are not. These buildings contain T12, HO lamps/ballasts and inefficient fixtures. This scope will update the lighting in these buildings to match the rest of the District. These savings estimates, like all lighting savings, are stipulated and will be field verified by a third party and are not part of the Solar Production Guarantee. 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$227,757.00
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Capitol Facilities
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve change order #1 for the expanded lighting at Santa Teresa High School.

Pursuant to the contract awarded by the Board of Trustees on May 20, 2010, PARC Services, Inc. has furnished all material and finished all labor for the completion of work related to James Lick High School, Demolition of Existing Building #500 Project.

$40,260.00
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Capital Facilities Fund
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Notice of Completion for James Lick High School, Demolition of Existing Child Care Center Project (PARC Services, Inc.).

With the approval of the Board of Trustees, the attached Notice of Completion will be filed with the Santa Clara County Recorder’s Office as required by law.
